Personally, I'm most interested in the intuitionistic case, where I can do Curry-Howard in the traditional way. But the motivation from topology is also very nice, of course.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Oct 13 2024 at 21:04):

I will give a 30 minutes talk at the Octoberfest with title « What’s wrong with higher-order derivatives? ».

I will talk about two issues with higher-order derivatives: 1. In positive characteristic, the derivative of a polynomial can be zero even if the polynomial is nonconstant! The notion of Hasse-Schmidt derivative comes to fix that. 2. In differential geometry the tangent bundle functor approximates linearly both manifolds and smooth maps. Can we work with approximations by polynomials of order two, three etc? The notion of higher-order tangent bundle is defined to handle this.

Then we’ll see how both of these concepts could maybe fit nicely together in the framework of differential and tangent categories.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Nov 08 2024 at 20:00):

I’ve realized something that is very clean and quite simple but that I haven’t (yet) found in the literature (which is a bit surprising):

« Every commutative differential (associative, don’t need unital) algebra is a Lie algebra. »

If (A,D) is your commutative differential algebra, you just have to define
[x,y]=D(x)y−xD(y) [x,y]=D(x)y-xD(y)[x,y]=D(x)y−xD(y).

A calculation of a dozen of lines shows that the Jacobi identity is satisfied. I guess if ever this is really not something well-known (which would be a shame) it must be because Lie algebra people are not much interested in differential algebra and reciprocally.

John Baez (Nov 09 2024 at 02:14):

Nice! I hadn't seen this. I don't instantly see a "high-level" argument to check the Jacobi identity, though I feel there must be one.

John Baez (Nov 09 2024 at 02:16):

Hmm: in the case when the commutative algebra AAA is the algebra C∞(R)C^\infty(\mathbb{R})C∞(R) of smooth real-valued functions on the line, we can check the Jacobi identity as follows.

We can identify such functions on real line with vector fields on the real line via the map sending

f∈C∞(R) f \in C^\infty(\mathbb{R}) f∈C∞(R)

to the vector field (= derivation)

fddx f \frac{d}{dx} fdxd​

(This map is an isomorphism of vector spaces.)

John Baez (Nov 09 2024 at 02:17):

Thus, we can use the Lie bracket on such vector fields to give C∞(R)C^\infty(\mathbb{R})C∞(R) a Lie bracket, and the Jacobi identity will follow.

John Baez (Nov 09 2024 at 02:18):

The Lie bracket on such vector fields is

[fddx,gddx]=fg′(x)ddx−gf′ddx [f \frac{d}{dx} , g \frac{d}{dx}] = f g'(x) \frac{d}{dx} - g f' \frac{d}{dx}[fdxd​,gdxd​]=fg′(x)dxd​−gf′dxd​

John Baez (Nov 09 2024 at 02:19):

The corresponding Lie bracket on C∞(R)C^\infty(\mathbb{R})C∞(R) is thus

[f,g]=fg′−gf′ [f,g] = fg' - gf'[f,g]=fg′−gf′

John Baez (Nov 09 2024 at 02:19):

But there is a derivation DDD on C∞(R)C^\infty(\mathbb{R})C∞(R) defined by

D(f)=f′ D(f) = f'D(f)=f′

John Baez (Nov 09 2024 at 02:20):

So, the above bracket on C∞(R)C^\infty(\mathbb{R})C∞(R) equals

[f,g]=fD(g)−gD(f) [f,g] = f D(g) - g D(f) [f,g]=fD(g)−gD(f)

which is a special case of your formula.

John Baez (Nov 09 2024 at 02:21):

In this special case, therefore, the Jacobi identity for your bracket follows from the well-known Jacobi identity for derivations on any commutative algebra.

John Baez (Nov 09 2024 at 02:22):

However, I don't see how to generalize this proof of the Jacobi identity to an arbitrary derivation on an arbitrary commutative algebra. I may be just missing a trick or two.

This is not a derivation of the ring of integers, but it's something called a 'p-derivation', and people are trying to develop the theory of these.

One thing to mention is that lambda-rings, differential rings, and delta-rings (which lie somewhere in the middle of the previous two) are all examples of plethories, and a certain amount of abstract nonsense about plethories can be developed that accounts for various structural similarities. One thing I want to understand much better is how the delta-rings connect with p-th Adams operations. Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Nov 09 2024 at 13:02):

Todd Trimble, this is super intriguing that both delta rings, lambda rings and differential rings are plethories. It makes me think to a question I had some time ago. Why do we have lambda rings but not an analogous definition for rings with a family of operations that behave like symmetric powers, or a family of operations that behave like the Schur functors?

Todd Trimble (Nov 09 2024 at 13:45):

We do! Lambda-rings could equally well have been called sigma-rings (sigma referring to symmetric powers), and likewise, for any Schur functor, there is a corresponding operation that is definable in the language of lambda-rings.

One way of saying it is that given a lambda-ring RRR, which in our first paper Schur functors and categorified plethysm we identify with a coalgebra of the comonad CRing(Λ,−)\mathsf{CRing}(\Lambda, -)CRing(Λ,−), and FFF is a Schur functor, the isomorphism class [F]∈Λ[F] \in \Lambda[F]∈Λ induces an operation on RRR by composition

R⟶ηCRing(Λ,R)⟶ev[F]RR \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} \mathsf{CRing}(\Lambda, R) \overset{\mathrm{ev}_{[F]}}{\longrightarrow} RR⟶η​CRing(Λ,R)⟶ev[F]​​R

where η\etaη is the coalgebra structure map and ev[F]\mathrm{ev}_{[F]}ev[F]​ denotes evaluation at [F][F][F]. This approach de-emphasizes playing favorites between operations λi\lambda^iλi and σi\sigma^iσi; in this sense it's an unbiased definition of λ\lambdaλ-ring.

One intriguing fact is that there is a ring involution ω:Λ→Λ\omega: \Lambda \to \Lambdaω:Λ→Λ which swaps the λi\lambda^iλi with the σi\sigma^iσi. (It is not however a lambda-ring involution.)

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Nov 09 2024 at 13:52):

Awesome!

John Baez (Nov 09 2024 at 15:54):

Todd Trimble said:

We do! Lambda-rings could equally well have been called sigma-rings (sigma referring to symmetric powers), and likewise, for any Schur functor, there is a corresponding operation that is definable in the language of lambda-rings.

One way of saying it is that given a lambda-ring RRR, which in our first paper Schur functors and categorified plethysm we identify with a coalgebra of the comonad CRing(Λ,−)\mathsf{CRing}(\Lambda, -)CRing(Λ,−), and FFF is a Schur functor, the isomorphism class [F]∈Λ[F] \in \Lambda[F]∈Λ induces an operation on RRR by composition

R⟶ηCRing(Λ,R)⟶ev[F]RR \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} \mathsf{CRing}(\Lambda, R) \overset{\mathrm{ev}_{[F]}}{\longrightarrow} RR⟶η​CRing(Λ,R)⟶ev[F]​​R

where η\etaη is the coalgebra structure map and ev[F]\mathrm{ev}_{[F]}ev[F]​ denotes evaluation at [F][F][F]. This approach de-emphasizes playing favorites between operations λi\lambda^iλi and σi\sigma^iσi; in this sense it's an unbiased definition of λ\lambdaλ-ring.

Of course that big fat Λ\LambdaΛ suggests there's something primary about the exterior power elements λi∈Λ\lambda^i \in \Lambdaλi∈Λ, but as Todd just noted, that's not true: it's really almost an arbitrary convention that people like to use these λi\lambda^iλi as generators of the ring Λ\LambdaΛ. The symmetric power elements σi\sigma^iσi also generate this ring, so we could have called this ring Σ\SigmaΣ.

I say it's almost arbitrary: I believe people lean toward the λi\lambda^iλi because they consider bosons to be more fundamental than fermions. Less cryptically: we discovered finite-dimensional "bosonic" vector spaces - ordinary vector spaces, whose exterior powers ΛiV\Lambda^i VΛiV vanish when iii exceeds the dimension of VVV - before we discovered "fermionic" vector spaces, whose symmetric powers ΣiV\Sigma^i VΣiV vanish when iii exceeds the dimension of VVV. And we still mainly use bosonic vector spaces.

(I usually write SiS^iSi for symmetric powers, and most people do, but here I'm trying to emphasize the battle of the greek letters λ\lambdaλ and σ\sigmaσ, just to be cute.)

The duality between exterior powers and symmetric powers became really clear in physics, where it's called 'supersymmetry'. Bosonic vector spaces are used to describe 'forces' and fermionic vector spaces are used to describe 'matter', and some physicists go wild and assert the existence of physical symmetries that switch forces and matter, but more interesting is that many structures in linear algebra have bosonic and fermionic versions, which behave analogously in some ways but very differently in practice.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Nov 09 2024 at 17:51):

Now I’m going to take a look at your paper to see what is this Λ\LambdaΛ!

Todd Trimble (Nov 09 2024 at 18:17):

I think we're happy to discuss it anytime. Λ\LambdaΛ is a decategorification (or Grothendieck group) of something more fundamental, which is the category of Schur functors, aka polynomial species valued in f.d. vector spaces (over a field of characteristic zero). So Λ\LambdaΛ is the result of taking the rig of isomorphism classes of Schur functors, which are objects of a 2-rig, and then completing this rig to a ring by adjoining additive inverses.

We show how all the structure that people talk about on Λ\LambdaΛ emerges just by exploiting the simple observation that the category of Schur functors is the free 2-rig on one generator (in our sense of 2-rig). In other words, we would like to promote the idea that actually Λ\LambdaΛ is conceptually simple, although it is often cloaked in awe and mystery. Another thing is that essentially all examples of lambda-rings that people discuss come from 2-rigs, so it actually makes better sense to start with 2-rigs.

The paper is kind of long and I gather that many people find it scary-looking, which works against the idea of simplicity we want to promote. So it could help to talk about it here on this Zulip, in a more informal way.

Todd Trimble (Nov 09 2024 at 18:38):

John wrote

we discovered finite-dimensional "bosonic" vector spaces... before we discovered "fermionic" vector spaces

where I think "we" here means the mathematics community. You can also have a mix of bosonic and fermionic.

One thing that makes fermionic vector spaces feel more alien is that they have negative dimension. Where "dimension" of an object is defined to be the trace of its identity operator. (The notion of trace makes sense in any compact closed category, a symmetric monoidal category where for every object VVV there is an object V∗V^\astV∗ together with a counit ε:V∗⊗V→I\varepsilon: V^\ast \otimes V \to Iε:V∗⊗V→I and unit η:I→V⊗V∗\eta: I \to V \otimes V^\astη:I→V⊗V∗ satisfying the usual triangular identities. The trace of an endomorphism f:V→Vf: V \to Vf:V→V is the endomorphism I→II \to II→I defined by the composite

I⟶ηV⊗V∗⟶f⊗1V⊗V∗≅V∗⊗V⟶εII \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} V \otimes V^\ast \overset{f \otimes 1}{\longrightarrow} V \otimes V^\ast \cong V^\ast \otimes V \overset{\varepsilon}{\longrightarrow} II⟶η​V⊗V∗⟶f⊗1​V⊗V∗≅V∗⊗V⟶ε​I

and this "scalar quantity" can be various weird things. I think the situation can get significantly weirder if you replace "symmetric monoidal" with "braided monoidal".)

In fact the philosophy behind our paper was to study representations of symmetric groups, and the ring Λ\LambdaΛ, without the 'crutch' of Young diagrams.

Todd Trimble (Nov 09 2024 at 20:10):

Well, I'd prefer not to say who came up with what, because that could excite my naturally territorial nature.

I would agree that in some sense much of what transpires in sections 1-6 is a bit more on the straightforward side, i.e., once you've taken the primacy of the importance of the free 2-rig on one generator fully into your heart and you've milked the Yoneda lemma enough times, the development probably seems natural and not terribly surprising. But the techniques in section 7 come from a different direction (although, there too, maybe not all that unexpected if you've done enough battle with the problems of negatives in category theory).

Despite what I just said, I thought it was sections 5, 6 that were the trickiest parts to get right, to put the ideas in the right categorical order. The basic conundrum was expressed by Clark Barwick at the n-Category Cafe:

The K-theory of a plethory is a plethory…

The punchline is the following: categorification takes a trivial plethory to a nontrivial plethory. This is just like redshift, which says that applying K-theory makes things more interesting!

I.e., [he meant decategorification, not categorification] how could decategorification turn something trivial into something non-trivial?? Usually I think decategorification is seen as moving in a simplifying direction, by ignoring the complications of non-isomorphisms, and turning isomorphisms into equalities.

Anyway, this is probably too much inside baseball or navel-gazing or something. John also said

John Baez said:

So when I see Λ\LambdaΛ, I see a vector space whose basis consists of Young diagrams. But this is probably just me! Someone else might see it in quite a different way. In fact the philosophy behind our paper was to study representations of symmetric groups, and the ring Λ\LambdaΛ, without the 'crutch' of Young diagrams.

Right -- I had in mind how to explain the basic simplicity to category theorists, who mostly don't know about Young diagrams. We don't even talk that much about representation theory, just a few basic facts. A lot of the message is that you really don't need to know Young diagrams or all the ins and outs of group representations; you can just think conceptually.

John is more fluid than I am with shuffling around Young tableaux. (These are also things that deserve a better categorical treatment than they have gotten, so far as I am aware.) There's something about the combinatorial arguments that underlie them in standard accounts that feels opaque to me [and some categorists I have spoken with feel similarly].

John Baez (Nov 12 2024 at 23:20):

No need to acknowledge me!

First, I was curious why you're writing +⟨Xp⟩ + \langle X^p \rangle+⟨Xp⟩ a bunch of times when you're working in k[X]/⟨Xp⟩k[X]/\langle X^p \ranglek[X]/⟨Xp⟩. Then I realized why you were doing that: elements of k[X]/⟨Xp⟩k[X]/\langle X^p \ranglek[X]/⟨Xp⟩ are really equivalence classes of the form something+⟨Xp⟩\text{something} + \langle X^p \ranglesomething+⟨Xp⟩.

But I think almost all algebraists would just omit writing +⟨Xp⟩ + \langle X^p \rangle+⟨Xp⟩ in situations like this, where we are working in a quotient ring k[X]/⟨Xp⟩k[X]/\langle X^p \ranglek[X]/⟨Xp⟩. We (they) just act like XpX^pXp has been set to zero.

One reason I bring this up is that a very short paper like this is unusual and it will make readers wonder "what has this guy discovered?" Then, if you write in an unorthodox (though technically correct) way, they may not give you the benefit of the doubt.

John Baez (Nov 12 2024 at 23:30):

Personally, I feel there's a very high probability this result is already in the literature somewhere. So if I discovered this result, I would start by asking on MathOverflow whether it was known. If it was known, then I would not write a short paper about it. If it wasn't known, I might write a paper about it. And my discovery would be documented on MathOverflow, with a date attached, so that anyone who tried to steal it would clearly be doing so later than this date.

(I would probably not write a 1-page paper about this result: I would probably try to find a really surprising fact based on this result, to increase the prestige payoff.)

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Nov 25 2024 at 14:42):

I said the other day that I don’t know whether

”every monoidal category such that every object is a a counital comagma in a unique way is a cartesian monoidal category” (⋆\star⋆)

On the other hand, it is true that

”every symmetric monoidal category such that every object is a a counital comagma in a unique way is a cartesian symmetric monoidal category” (⋆⋆\star\star⋆⋆)

Now, I think (⋆\star⋆) is false. I wrote a sequent calculus to try to build such a category:

IMG_1311.jpeg

This is obtained by starting from a sequent calculus for the fragment {and,true} \{and, true\}{and,true} of intuitionnistic logic, written in a linear fashion and then removing exchange.

I don’t know whether cut elimination works but I just want to post this here in order that I can come back to this later.

Alexis Toumi (Dec 11 2024 at 13:14):

Hey I think I found a way to prove that your statement (⋆)(\star)(⋆) is actually true: for any pair of objects A,BA, BA,B we can construct a natural isomorphism σAB:A⊗B→B⊗A\sigma_{AB} : A \otimes B \to B \otimes AσAB​:A⊗B→B⊗A given by (ϵA⊗B)⊗(A⊗ϵB)∘ΔA⊗B(\epsilon_A \otimes B) \otimes (A \otimes \epsilon_B) \circ \Delta_{A \otimes B}(ϵA​⊗B)⊗(A⊗ϵB​)∘ΔA⊗B​, i.e. copy their tensor product then discard the LHS of the LHS and the RHS of the RHS.

Edit: Actually I don't think you can prove σAB\sigma_{AB}σAB​ is an isomorphism, only that σBA∘σAB=(A⊗ϵB)⊗(ϵA⊗B)∘ΔA⊗B\sigma_{BA} \circ \sigma_{AB} = (A \otimes \epsilon_B) \otimes (\epsilon_A \otimes B) \circ \Delta_{A \otimes B}σBA​∘σAB​=(A⊗ϵB​)⊗(ϵA​⊗B)∘ΔA⊗B​ but it seems like it's possible for this to be different from the identity.

Alexis Toumi (Dec 11 2024 at 14:25):

So we can formulate something like "Every monoidal category (C,⊗,I)(C, \otimes, I)(C,⊗,I) with a pair of natural transformations ΔA:A→A⊗A,ϵA:A→I\Delta_A : A \to A \otimes A, \epsilon_A : A \to IΔA​:A→A⊗A,ϵA​:A→I which is coherent in the sense that ϵA⊗B=ϵA⊗ϵB\epsilon_{A \otimes B} = \epsilon_A \otimes \epsilon_BϵA⊗B​=ϵA​⊗ϵB​ and (A⊗ϵB)⊗(ϵA⊗B)∘ΔA⊗B=idA⊗B(A \otimes \epsilon_B) \otimes (\epsilon_A \otimes B) \circ \Delta_{A \otimes B} = id_{A \otimes B}(A⊗ϵB​)⊗(ϵA​⊗B)∘ΔA⊗B​=idA⊗B​ is a cartesian symmetric monoidal category".

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Dec 11 2024 at 15:33):

Your final statement looks very similar to Proposition 16 (section 6.4) in Categorical semantics of linear logic. In a remark after the proof he says that you can replace comonoid by counital comagma in the proposition. So the only difference with what you write is the ϵA⊗B=ϵA⊗ϵB\epsilon_{A \otimes B}=\epsilon_A \otimes \epsilon_BϵA⊗B​=ϵA​⊗ϵB​ for you vs ϵI=idI\epsilon_I=\mathrm{id}_IϵI​=idI​ for him.

But now that you say you can build this σA,B\sigma_{A,B}σA,B​, I feel like (⋆)(\star)(⋆) could be true, maybe. Do you actually use this σA,B\sigma_{A,B}σA,B​ to prove the final statement?

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Dec 11 2024 at 15:38):

On the other hand, finding an example of a category which satisfy (⋆)(\star)(⋆) but such that the σA,B\sigma_{A,B}σA,B​ are not isomorphisms could be the way to go to disprove (⋆)(\star)(⋆).

In fact both my condition ϵA⊗B=ϵA⊗ϵB\epsilon_{A \otimes B} = \epsilon_A \otimes \epsilon_BϵA⊗B​=ϵA​⊗ϵB​ and Melies' condition ϵI=idI\epsilon_I = id_IϵI​=idI​ are trivially satisfied: the naturality of ϵ:A→I\epsilon : A \to Iϵ:A→I is equivalent to asking for the monoidal unit III to be a terminal object, from which we can derive these two equations.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Dec 22 2024 at 20:09):

I want to write something here in order to archive it. I think this concept should be interesting. The idea is to give a definition in the spirit of differential categories but much closer to usual mathematics, in particular differential algebra (in fact it should be a special case of a basic definition in differential algebra).

I want to define a functional differential ring as a differential ring (R,D)(R,D)(R,D) together with an associative and unital operation ∘:R×R→R\circ:R \times R \rightarrow R∘:R×R→R such that:

  • (f⋅g)∘h=(f∘h)⋅(g∘h)(f \cdot g) \circ h = (f \circ h) \cdot (g \circ h)(f⋅g)∘h=(f∘h)⋅(g∘h)
  • 1∘f=11 \circ f=11∘f=1
  • (f+g)∘h=(f∘h)+(g∘h)(f+g) \circ h=(f \circ h)+(g \circ h)(f+g)∘h=(f∘h)+(g∘h)
  • D(f∘g)=D(f)∘D(g)D(f \circ g)=D(f) \circ D(g)D(f∘g)=D(f)∘D(g)

I think we can prove the Faà di Bruno's formula in a functional differential ring. And a consequence of the Faà di Bruno's formula should be that a functional differential ring somehow (I'm not sure what should be the exact definition) admits an (N∪{∞})(\mathbb{N} \cup \{\infty\})(N∪{∞})-filtration by defining kern(D)={r∈R, Dn+1(r)=0}\mathrm{ker}_n(D)=\{r \in R,~D^{n+1}(r)=0\}kern​(D)={r∈R, Dn+1(r)=0} (that we could call the subset of polynomials of degree ≤n\le n≤n) because the Faà di Bruno's formula should imply that if f∈kern(D)f \in \mathrm{ker}_n(D)f∈kern​(D) and g∈kerp(D)g \in \mathrm{ker}_p(D)g∈kerp​(D), then f∘g∈kernp(D)f \circ g \in \mathrm{ker}_{np}(D)f∘g∈kernp​(D).

The most obvious example of a functional differential ring should be the set of C∞\mathcal{C}^\inftyC∞ functions from R\mathbb{R}R to R\mathbb{R}R.

If you start with a category C\mathcal{C}C, choose an object A∈CA \in \mathcal{C}A∈C and a morphism f∈C[A,A]f \in \mathcal{C}[A,A]f∈C[A,A], then you can look at the category ⟨f⟩\langle f \rangle⟨f⟩ generated by the morphism fff consisting of the object AAA and all the composites fn:A→Af^n:A \rightarrow Afn:A→A for any n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N. I often think about composition in terms of its combinatorial properties and set partitions. Bell diagrams are a nice way to visualize composition. As opposed to iterated functions which can algebraically be expanded out indefinitely, recursive set partitions terminate. I define Schröder diagrams as recursive Bell diagrams.

Daniel Geisler (Dec 23 2024 at 01:35):

I did a search for set partitions in OEIS and then searched for "category". I found one hit, # Updown categories: Generating functions and universal covers

A poset can be regarded as a category in which there is at most one morphism between objects, and such that at most one of Hom(c,c') and Hom(c',c) is nonempty for distinct objects c,c'. If we keep in place the latter axiom but allow for more than one morphism between objects, we have a sort of generalized poset in which there are multiplicities attached to covering relations, and possibly nontrivial automorphism groups. We call such a category an "updown category". In this paper we give a precise definition of such categories and develop a theory for them. We also give a detailed account of ten examples, including updown categories of integer partitions, integer compositions, planar rooted trees, and rooted trees.

Todd Trimble (Dec 23 2024 at 02:21):

John Baez said:

So I realize I don't even know what the free commutative differential ring on one generator is. Is it the polynomial ring on infinitely many commuting generators x,x′,x′′,x′′′,…x, x', x'', x''', \dotsx,x′,x′′,x′′′,…?

Yes, for the usual notion of differential ring, with the number of ′^\prime′ strokes indicating the order of derivative of the formal variable xxx.

The linearity and Leibnitz rules provide a distributive law DF→FDDF \to FDDF→FD where DDD is the monad for the theory of an unary operator (i.e., the monad N×−\mathbb{N} \times -N×−) which here is to be interpreted as the derivative, and FFF is the free commutative ring monad. It then follows that the free commutative differential ring on a set SSS is F(N×S)F(\mathbb{N} \times S)F(N×S).

Here's another thing: there's something called Hadamard's lemma, about the ring of C∞C^\inftyC∞ functions f:R→Rf: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}f:R→R. It says that for any such fff and any a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R, there's a unique C∞C^\inftyC∞ function ggg such that

f(x)=f(a)+(x−a)g(x)f(x) = f(a) + (x - a)g(x)f(x)=f(a)+(x−a)g(x)

This is something that can be formulated in the language of functional rings as it stands so far, so might it be worth considering as an axiom? In connection with this, I'm reminded of this MO post.

John Baez (Dec 23 2024 at 04:49):

Since your functional differential rings are described by a [[Lawvere theory]] - that is, a bunch of operations obeying equational laws - we know that a free functional differential ring exists on any set of generators. So we don't need to develop a rewriting system to get that. We might want a confluent terminating rewriting system to describe the free functional different ring on one or more generators in an "explicit" way, as a set of normal forms.

Here's another approach, sort of weird:

Conjecture. For all functions f∈C∞(R)f \in C^\infty(\mathbb{R})f∈C∞(R) except those in a meager set (a countable union of nowhere dense sets), the functional differential ring generated by fff is the free functional differential ring on one generator.

Here we could use the Whitney topology on C∞(R)C^\infty(\mathbb{R})C∞(R), which has the advantage that the complement of a meager set is dense.

In other words: the derivatives and composites of most smooth functions f:R→Rf : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}f:R→R don't obey any special relations that can be stated in the language of functional differential rings.

John Baez (Dec 23 2024 at 04:56):

We might be able to prove the conjecture if we use the fact that there are just countably many equations that we need to prevent fff from obeying. Then, we'd need to show that equation holds only for fff in some nowhere dense set.

John Baez (Dec 23 2024 at 04:56):

But this is only a fun challenge for people who like analysis!

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Dec 23 2024 at 17:34):

Here is my very simple-minded approach.

Step 1: Define a set YYY by induction as follows:

  • I,0,1,f∈YI,0,1,f \in YI,0,1,f∈Y
  • if x∈Fx \in Fx∈F, then −x∈Y-x \in Y−x∈Y,
  • if x,y∈Fx,y \in Fx,y∈F, then x+y,x⋅y,x∘y∈Yx+y,x \cdot y, x \circ y \in Yx+y,x⋅y,x∘y∈Y

Step 2: Define an equivalence relation RRR induced by all the equations in the definition of functional differential ring.

Step 3: Define F=Y/RF=Y/RF=Y/R.

Chris Barrett (Jan 15 2025 at 16:23):

Hey Jean-Baptiste! I have been toying with the idea recently of developing a variant of (graded) differential linear logic with an exponential based on the exterior algebra functor rather than the symmetric algebra functor. After a bit of googling, I saw you mentioned something along these lines in one of your talks and elsewhere on this forum. Initially I thought the graded (anti-)commutativity might be problematic to axiomatize, but graded DiLL may help solve this problem. I'm interested in developing a sequent calculus (and so computational interpretation via cut elimination); it's not yet perfectly clear to me how anti-commutativity might play with proof equivalence via cut-elimination, but I have some hope it's not an insurmountable problem.

The tensor algebra functor is a (comonoidal) monad, so I would have thought that it remains a monad after the quotienting needed to get the exterior algebra functor. But maybe I've missed something!

(Note, I don't want to step on your toes if you're actively working on this -- I'm currently playing around more for my personal interest than for the purposes of publication.)

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Jan 16 2025 at 13:00):

If you have a codifferential category C,!,…\mathcal{C},!,\dotsC,!,… (i.e. Cop\mathcal{C}^{op}Cop is a differential category) and a graded-commutative N\mathbb{N}N-graded algebra modality (Λn:C→C)n≥0(\Lambda^n:\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C})_{n \ge 0}(Λn:C→C)n≥0​ (i.e. you have natural transformations which make each (Λn(A))n≥0(\Lambda^n(A))_{n \ge 0}(Λn(A))n≥0​ into a graded-commutative N\mathbb{N}N-graded algebra), then you can define the exterior derivative like this:

!A⊗Λn(A)⟶dA⊗1!A \otimes \Lambda^n(A) \overset{d_A \otimes 1}{\longrightarrow}!A⊗Λn(A)⟶dA​⊗1​
!A⊗A⊗Λn(A)⟶1⊗γ!A \otimes A \otimes \Lambda^n(A) \overset{1 \otimes \gamma}{\longrightarrow}!A⊗A⊗Λn(A)⟶1⊗γ​
!A⊗Λn(A)⊗A⟶1⊗multn,1!A⊗Λn+1(A)!A \otimes \Lambda^n(A) \otimes A \overset{1 \otimes \mathrm{mult}_{n,1}}{\longrightarrow} !A \otimes \Lambda^{n+1}(A)!A⊗Λn(A)⊗A⟶1⊗multn,1​​!A⊗Λn+1(A)

If you add these Λn\Lambda^nΛn to a sequent calculus for codifferential categories, then you should be able to write a proof which is the exterior derivative of differential nnn-forms :)

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Jan 16 2025 at 13:08):

Adding the Hodge star to this is an exciting idea. It’s more intimidating to me for at least two reasons:

  • I’m not sure whether the Hodge star is a natural transformation
  • You can define the Hodge star of elements of Λn(A)\Lambda^n(A)Λn(A) for a finite-dimensional vector space AAA. But differential categories need infinite-dimensionality because of !A!A!A which is never finite-dimensional. A solution could be to replace the monad by a relative monad (for instance from FVec\mathbf{FVec}FVec to Vec\mathbf{Vec}Vec) giving maybe a notion of relative differential category

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Jan 16 2025 at 13:19):

Of course here we’re talking about differential forms on vector spaces and not manifolds but this is what we will get if we start with linear logic

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Jan 20 2025 at 21:26):

The other day, I sent a title and abstract to my supervisor to give a talk at the logic seminar of uOttawa presenting the idea of functional differential ring. Then, I got two other ideas I'm excited about!

1) Given an algebraic theory T\mathcal{T}T (in the sense of universal algebra), I would like to give a sequent calculus, with cut elimination which build morphisms in the category of T\mathcal{T}T-algebras. (or more generally the category of T\mathcal{T}T-algebras in any cartesian category). But it requires to give an orientation to the equations. So I'm wondering whether we could not define a notion of "directed algebraic theory" and whether we can't give a sequent calculus associated to every directed algebraic theory.

2) Given a category C\mathcal{C}C with finite products, I would like to look at all the natural transformations of the type A×n→A×pA^{\times n} \rightarrow A^{\times p}A×n→A×p and then at the equations statisfied by combining them. I would want to give a symbol for each of these natural transformations and then look at all the equations satisfied by combining these symbols by using products and composition. I hope that I could associate an algebraic theory TC\mathcal{T}_\mathcal{C}TC​ to any cartesian category C\mathcal{C}C in this way. Then I would want to look at a forgetful functor U:C→AlgTCU:\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathrm{Alg}_{\mathcal{T}_\mathcal{C}}U:C→AlgTC​​ defined by UC(A)=AlgTC[⊤,A]U_\mathcal{C}(A)=\mathrm{Alg}_{\mathcal{T}_\mathcal{C}}[\top,A]UC​(A)=AlgTC​​[⊤,A]. And I would want that C\mathcal{C}C is isomorphic to a variety of algebras iff UCU_\mathcal{C}UC​ is an isomorphism in Cat\mathbf{Cat}Cat which preserves products (or something close to this).

It must be easier to understand this idea once you realize that the fact that A×A→AA \times A \rightarrow AA×A→A which does (a,b)↦ab(a,b) \mapsto ab(a,b)↦ab is a natural transformation in Grp\mathbf{Grp}Grp means exactly that group homomorphisms preserve the multiplication for instance. Starting from this observation, I hope that analyzing all such natural transformations in a cartesian category would reveal the underlying algebraic structure. For instance, if we take C\mathcal{C}C to be the category of topological monoids, I would like TC\mathcal{T}_\mathcal{C}TC​ to be the algebraic theory of monoids etc... Still thinking about whether this idea really makes sense and how to organize it.

Nathanael Arkor (Jan 20 2025 at 22:20):

Regarding (1), I think that you're essentially describing the notion of "algebraic 2-theory", which is a 2-categorical generalisation of algebraic theories. Perhaps a place to start looking is Yanofsky's The Syntax of Coherence.

Nathanael Arkor (Jan 20 2025 at 22:25):

Regarding (2), I think a key phrase is "structure and semantics". In his thesis, Lawvere defined a (partial) functor CAT/Set→AlgTh\mathrm{CAT}/\mathrm{Set} \to \mathrm{AlgTh}CAT/Set→AlgTh (called the "structure" functor), which constructs the algebraic theory for which the forgetful functor from the category of algebras best approximates the given functor. One nice introduction to these ideas is Faro–Kelly's On the canonical algebraic structure of a category.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Jan 20 2025 at 22:27):

Thanks! I’ll take a look at these two papers.

Nathanael Arkor (Jan 20 2025 at 22:28):

If you take the forgetful functor from the category of groups to sets, then the induced algebraic theory is precisely the theory of groups. However, if you take the forgetful functor from the category of topological groups to topological spaces, I would not be surprised if you don't get precisely the category of groups, because I would imagine there are operations/equations satisfied by every topological group that are not satisfied by every set group (though I haven't thought about it in any detail).

John Baez (Jan 20 2025 at 22:28):

If an algebraic theory is a category with finite products, and an algebraic 2-theory is a 2-category with finite products (I don't know if that's what Nathaniel is referring to), Jean-Baptiste might enjoy thinking about algebraic 1½-theories, i.e. 1½-categories with finite products - by which I mean poset-enriched categories with finite products. This is enough to talk about 'directed' equations, i.e. rewrite rules.

(I am jokingly using '1½-category' to mean poset-enriched category, also known as a [[posetal category]]. They sit somewhere between 1-categories and full-fledged 2-categories. But this is just a joke, not a serious piece of terminology - and you shouldn't mix them up with [[sesquicategories]].)

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Jan 20 2025 at 23:20):

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Jan 21 2025 at 11:47):

If you can do a logic like this for monoids, it should be something like a logic of the category of monoids and more maps than just homomorphisms of monoids (maybe we could say « monomial maps »).

There are things in linear logic that you can’t do, that here you could do. For instance, in linear logic you can do ?A→?A×?A?A \rightarrow ?A \times ?A?A→?A×?A which does x↦(x,x)x \mapsto (x,x)x↦(x,x) and then ?A⊗?A→?A?A \otimes ?A \rightarrow ?A?A⊗?A→?A which does (x,y)→xy(x,y) \rightarrow xy(x,y)→xy but you can’t compose the two because of types.

Here you should be able to do A→A×AA \rightarrow A \times AA→A×A which does x↦(x,x)x \mapsto (x,x)x↦(x,x) followed by A×A→AA \times A \rightarrow AA×A→A which does (x,y)→xy(x,y) \rightarrow xy(x,y)→xy giving a map A→AA \rightarrow AA→A which does x↦x2x \mapsto x^2x↦x2.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Feb 23 2025 at 22:03):

I may have found a variant of the notion of tensor product of modules.

Let RRR be a commutative ring and let E,FE,FE,F be two RRR-modules.

For every RRR-module GGG, say that a function f:E×F→Gf:E \times F \rightarrow Gf:E×F→G is left linear if for all a,b∈Ea,b \in Ea,b∈E, c∈Fc \in Fc∈F and λ∈R\lambda \in Rλ∈R, we have

  • f(a+b,c)=f(a,c)+f(b,c)f(a+b,c)=f(a,c)+f(b,c)f(a+b,c)=f(a,c)+f(b,c) for all a,b∈Ea,b \in Ea,b∈E and c∈Fc \in Fc∈F,
  • f(λa,c)=λf(a,b)f(\lambda a,c)=\lambda f(a,b)f(λa,c)=λf(a,b) for all a∈E,c∈Fa \in E, c \in Fa∈E,c∈F and λ∈R\lambda \in Rλ∈R.

Does there exists an RRR-module E◃FE \triangleleft FE◃F with a left linear map ϕ:E×F→E◃F\phi:E \times F \rightarrow E \triangleleft Fϕ:E×F→E◃F such that for every left linear map f:E×F→Gf:E \times F \rightarrow Gf:E×F→G, there exists a unique left linear map g:E◃F→Gg:E \triangleleft F \rightarrow Gg:E◃F→G satisfying f=ϕ∘gf=\phi \circ gf=ϕ∘g?

Well... Define E◃FE \triangleleft FE◃F has the quotient of F(E×F)\mathcal{F}(E \times F)F(E×F) the free RRR-module on E×FE \times FE×F by the sub RRR-module spanned by the (λa,c)−λ(a,c)(\lambda a,c)-\lambda(a,c)(λa,c)−λ(a,c) and the (a+b,c)−(a,c)−(b,c)(a+b,c)-(a,c)-(b,c)(a+b,c)−(a,c)−(b,c). We get a quotient map ϕ:E×F→E◃F\phi:E \times F \rightarrow E \triangleleft Fϕ:E×F→E◃F which is left linear. Write a∙b:=f(a,b)a \bullet b :=f(a,b)a∙b:=f(a,b).

Define g:E◃F→Gg: E \triangleleft F \rightarrow Gg:E◃F→G as the unique linear map such that g(a∙b)=f(a,b)g(a \bullet b)=f(a,b)g(a∙b)=f(a,b). This is well-defined by left linearity of ggg.

I guess everything works fine, E◃FE \triangleleft FE◃F is unique up to isomorphism...

Why do I care about that?

The composition map C∞(R)×C∞(R)→C∞(R)\mathcal{C}^\infty(\mathbb{R}) \times \mathcal{C}^\infty(\mathbb{R}) \rightarrow \mathcal{C}^\infty(\mathbb{R})C∞(R)×C∞(R)→C∞(R) is left linear, the evaluation map C∞(R)×R→R\mathcal{C}^\infty(\mathbb{R}) \times \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}C∞(R)×R→R is left linear.

If everything works fine, we should be able to see them as linear map C∞(R)◃C∞(R)→C∞(R)\mathcal{C}^\infty(\mathbb{R}) \triangleleft \mathcal{C}^\infty(\mathbb{R}) \rightarrow \mathcal{C}^\infty(\mathbb{R})C∞(R)◃C∞(R)→C∞(R) and C∞(R)◃R→R\mathcal{C}^\infty(\mathbb{R}) \triangleleft \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}C∞(R)◃R→R.

In fact, I thought about this while looking at a "functional differential operads" which axiomatize calculus on the family of the C∞(Rn,R)\mathcal{C}^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n,\mathbb{R})C∞(Rn,R) for n≥1n \ge 1n≥1. This is the multivariate version of a functional differential ring. It seems that we can build a functional differential operad from every functional differential ring by using the idea that C∞(Rn,R)≃C∞(R,R)⊗^n\mathcal{C}^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n,\mathbb{R}) \simeq \mathcal{C}^\infty(\mathbb{R},\mathbb{R})^{\hat{\otimes} n}C∞(Rn,R)≃C∞(R,R)⊗^​n (which is actually a theorem). Then I was thinking to whether every functional differential operad arises in this way and this idea of left tensor product somehow came to my mind.

I can't talk much about this now because I have two midterms in a few days but I was not able to resist sharing this. In fact that's almost impossible to me not to share ideas which seems really cool with other people, else I feel they are going to make me crazy! so I write something here to avoid an implosion of my brain.

Mike Shulman (Feb 24 2025 at 00:23):

Yes, that's right! However, notice that in the definition of left linearity, and the construction of E◃FE\triangleleft FE◃F, you didn't use the RRR-module structure on FFF at all. So FFF could have been just a set. Now from this perspective, a left linear map E×F→GE\times F \to GE×F→G is equivalently a set-function F→hom⁡R(E,G)F \to \hom_R(E,G)F→homR​(E,G), and so E◃FE\triangleleft FE◃F is the [[copower]] of EEE by the set FFF in RRR-modules, or equivalently the coproduct of FFF copies of EEE.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (Feb 24 2025 at 00:25):
